ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We were assigned readings and videos/ movie.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to speak, read, and write Spanish at a higher level. I also learned more about the Spanish and Latino cultures.
I improved my grammar, writing, and speaking in spanish. However, a lot of the work was similar to SPAN 120.
Spanish grammar, speaking, writing and comprehension.
I learned how to use more verb tenses in more ways.
some new knowledge of future tenses, more in-depth vocabulary for health/medicine, travel, and emotions
I developed my Spanish speaking skills. I had seen most things in the "grammar department." However, I will say I have improved on grammar as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main strength was the teaching. Professor Najera was engaging, understanding, and kind. The weakness came from the way the course itself was structured: everything we did felt rushed, without time to truly understand the concepts we learned. I felt that tests, essays, and quizzes were thrown in the coursework without any real time to review or synthesize what we had learned.
I think the structure and schedule of assignments and tests could be improved. I felt like we had a test/quiz almost every week, and never a break or time to really improve my spanish grammatically.
weaknesses: lack of relevance and coordination of in-class and outside-of-class activities, lack of a well-structured/organized syllabus
I thought the live lectures motivated a learning environment, but I don't foresee live lectures being taken away from the Spanish department. I guess this comment isn't particularly helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the VHL SS homework was a good and efficient way to do homework while learning virtually. The in-class essays were not as successful, because it was really hard to complete a good essay while switching between tabs of instructions, pictures, and writing.

I liked how my professor incorporated activities that evoked high participation and engagement from all the students. We read many interesting cultural readings and watched videos of spanish culture, which I found very enjoyable.
I think there still should be spanish everday. We needed more time to speak.
the breakout rooms on zoom were successful and helped my learning, the feeling of a classroom community over zoom should be improved.
The thing that could be improved is tying in some of the earlier readings in the book to the grammar and vocab. It was "there" so to speak, but it was not an engaging "there."

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would, but I would warn them that they need to be proactive in reviewing for assignments by themselves, because there really is almost no time during class allocated for reviewing.
Yes, but only if you have taken Span 120 or placed into 130 and feel confident in your speaking.

No, because although my professor, Prof. Najera is very talented and lucid in her explanations and very understanding in her accommodations, she was constrained by a very rigid and fast-paced syllabus that did not allow individual flexibility for instructors.

if you are committed to learning Spanish and enjoy it, you can take the course to continue building your spanish skills. if you are not super invested in learning spanish, you might find yourself frustrated with the slight repetitiveness of the syllabus content and of the busy work
I would since it's the most rigorous course for Spanish so far. It definitely pushes one's limits in Spanish.
